Con el préstamo de S/. 1,800, el cual será pagará en 5 meses, comparará 5 cajas de panetones, 5 cajas de leche, 5 cajas de chocolates, 3 sacos de papa, 2 sacos de cebollas y variedad de verduras. Ysabel se siente muy feliz porque Manuela Ramos es un gran apoyo, también se siente que está progresando en todos los aspectos de su vida.

loans.use: Buying vegetables and others like: milk, chocolates, etc to sell at her business

loans.name: Elena Aurora

texts.es:
Elena Aurora P. R. is a married mother of two school-aged children. Since she was very young she has demonstrated the skill to make milk desserts, a skill she inherited from her mother that held her as an apprentice for a very long time. In her home, there is she and her husband and their two small children whom she and her husband together help support.

Poverty has devasted this family for a long time and to mitigate they have seen the obligation to start a business making these delicious desserts that they sell in the main market of Chichigalpa. Their primary need right now is the acquisition of ingredients to make their desserts.

Elena has been working with CEPRODEL since last year and she feels very satisfied with the timely support of the credit that has been granted her, helping her fill the needs of her business and therefore satisfy the daily demands of her clientele. She has a history of 7 loans.

Translated from Spanish by Erika Lindig, Kiva Volunteer.

Elena Aurora P. R. es madre casada y con dos hijos en la edad escolar. Desde muy niña tiene la habilidad de elaborar cuajadas heredando esta habilidad de su madre quien le enseñó por mucho tiempo hasta haber aprendido por completo. Su hogar consta de ella, su esposo y dos hijos pequeños a los cuales junto con su esposo deben mantener a sus pequeños.

Debido a la pobreza que ha atravesado por mucho tiempo esta familia, se han visto en la obligación de trabajar en la elaboración de estas riquísimas cuajadas que son comercializadas en el mercado municipal de Chichigalpa. Su mayor necesidad en este momento es la adquisición de la materia prima para elaborar las cuajadas.

La señora Elena trabaja con CEPRODEL desde hace 1 años y se siente muy satisfecha con los créditos otorgados pues les han sido brindados en el momento oportuno, ayudando a sí a suplir las necesidades del negocio y satisfacer a diario a su clientela. Ella tiene un record de 7 créditos.

loans.use: Purchase milk to make her product.

loans.name: Sergio Napoleon

texts.es:
Mr. Sergio Napoleon N. is originally from the city of Bluefields.  He is 56 years of age and is married to Mrs. Mercedes Guatemala.  Together they have six children that are in elementary school and university.  Their studies are paid for by Sergio’s sale of newspapers, which he has done for more than 35 years.  His customers are government institutions, restaurants and city locals who prefer him because he offers such personalized services.  At this time he needs to buy 509 units of newspapers at .21 cents to be able to satisfy his customers’ demands.

Translated from Spanish by Kiva Volunteer, Wendy Wise

El Sr. Sergio Napoleón N. es originario de la ciudad de Bluefields, tiene 56 años de edad esta casado con la Sra. Mercedes Guatemala ambos tienen 6 hijos que estudian en la primaria y en la universidad sus estudios son pagados con el ingreso de la venta de periódicos, tiene mas de 35 años de experiencia, sus clientes potenciales son las instituciones del gobierno, ONG, restaurantes y habitantes de la ciudad que lo prefieren por brindar un servicio personalizado y a domicilio en estos momentos necesita comprar 509 unidades de periódicos a $0.21 centavos dólar para poder satisfacer la demanda de sus clients

loans.use: To purchase 509 units of newspaper.  Comprar 509 unidades de periódicos.

payments.comment: La cuota real de pago es de $ 17.83 dólares.
La cuota real de pago es de $17.83 dólares.
La cuota real es de $ 17.83 dólares

loans.name: Beatriz

texts.es:
Mrs Beatriz belongs to the Community Bank “Solidarity” and she lives in Federico Basadre- Km 8, Urb. San Borja Mz. G, Lot number 10 in the district of Calleria, department of Ucayali. She is 32 years old, has 5 children under 18, is married and her husband is a motorcycle rickshaws driver.

She already received a first loan of 300 soles (100 USD) from the association Manuela Ramos which she invested in the maintenance of her motorcycle rickshaw.

Currently, she owns a stand where she sells chicken, a motorcycle rickshaw and a car which she uses for public transportation. She wakes up every morning at 4am to go to the market, where she has her stand and in the evenings she takes care of her children and the household.

With the loan of 1500 soles (525 USD), which she will pay in 5 months, she will buy wholesale chicken and she will give maintenance to her motorcycle rickshaw.

Beatriz is a very hard working woman and even though she is busy with her different businesses she still finds the time to spend happy moments with her family. She feels very happy about the support that the association Manuela Ramos is providing her.

Translated from Spanish by Jimena Almendares Leistner, Kiva Volunteer.

Description La señora Beatriz pertenece al Banco Comunal Solidaridad, vive en Carret Federico Basadre- Km, 8 Urb. San Borja Mz. G Lt. 10, del Distrito de Calleria del Departamento de Ucayali.

Tiene 32 años y es madre de cinco hijos menores de edad, su esposo es motocarrista.

Beatriz, con el primer préstamo recibido de Manuela Ramos de S/. 300 soles decidió invertir en el mantenimiento de su motokar.

En la actualidad ella cuenta con un puesto de venta de pollos (aves de consumo), un motokar y un auto con los que realizan servicios de transporte público, se levanta a las 4 a.m. para ir al mercado donde tiene un puesto de venta de pollos y por las tardes se dedica al cuidado de sus hijos y los quehaceres domésticos de su hogar. Con éste préstamo de S/. 1,500 soles, el cual será pagado en 5 meses, comprará pollos al por mayor y también dará mantenimiento a su motokar. Beatriz es una mujer muy trabajadora, a pesar que tiene varios negocios, no es ningún inconveniente para poder disfrutar momentos agradables con su familia, se siente feliz por el apoyo que le esta brindando Manuela Ramos.

loans.use: To buy chicken and give maintenance to her motorcycle rickshaw

loans.name: Eleuteria De Los Áng

texts.es:
Eleuteria de los Angeles M. is a married lady with 7 school aged children. This woman's business sells vegetables; she has been doing so for 6 years. She tells us that when her husband was left without a job, she had to find a way to survive and give her children what she did not have in her childhood- things such as an education. She then started this business of selling fruits and vegetables in order to provide her family with stability and a future education for her children.

Eleuteria started this business six years ago. She says she has always done well in the business since she has known how to invest wisely when purchasing perishable goods. An advantage her business has is that it is located in the municipal market of Chichigalpa which is visited by different people all day long.

Eleuteria has worked with CEPRODEL for 4 years now and feels greatly benefited with the loans given since they have been extended at opportune moments and have helped her meet the needs of the business and satisfy her clientele on a daily basis. She has a record of 19 loans and her main need at this moment is to buy vegetables and fruits to sell.

Translated from Spanish by Natalie Kane, Kiva Volunteer.

Eleuteria de los Ángeles M. , es una dama casada y con 7 hijos en edad escolar, el negocio de esta señora es la venta de verduras, tiene 6 años de tener este negocio, nos cuenta que cuando su esposo queda sin trabajo ella tiene que buscar la forma de sobre vivir y darle a sus hijos lo que ella no tuvo en su niñez como es la educación, inicia el negocio de la venta de frutas y verduras con el fin de brindarle a su familia estabilidad y una educación para el futuro de sus hijos.

Este negocio lo comenzó hace seis años, nos cuenta que en el negocio siempre le ha ido bien ya que ha sabido invertir bien el dinero en la compra de estos perecederos. Una ventaja que posee su negocio es que por estar ubicado en el mercado municipal de Chichigalpa, es muy visitado por diferentes personas en todo el día.

Eleuteria trabaja con CEPRODEL desde hace 4 años y se siente muy beneficiada con los créditos otorgados pues les han sido brindados en el momento oportuno, ayudando así a suplir las necesidades del negocio y satisfacer a diario a su clientela. Ella tiene un record de 19 créditos y su mayor necesidad en este momento es que necesita comprar las verduras y frutas para comercializarlas.

loans.use: Purchase fruits and vegetables

loans.name: Irma

texts.es:
La señora Irma  pertenece al Banco Comunal Solidaridad, vive en Jr. Maya de Britto 651, del Distrito de Calleria  del Departamento de Ucayali. Tiene 47 años y es madre de cuatro hijos  menores de edad, su esposo es chofer (transportista). Gracias al primer préstamo recibido de Manuela Ramos de S/. 300 soles, Beatriz decide invertir en una pequeña bodega.

En la actualidad ella cuenta con una bodega instalada en su propia casa, la misma que atiende con el apoyo de sus hijos, se levanta a las 6 a.m. para abrir su negocio y atender a sus clientes hasta las 10 pm. Simultáneamente atiende los quehaceres del hogar.

Con éste préstamo de S/. 2,000 soles, el cual será pagado en 5 meses, comprará 2 sacos de arroz, 2 sacos de azúcar, 3 cajas de aceite, 2 cajas de leche, 3 paquetes de fideos, 5 cajas de gaseosas, 2 bolsas de detergentes, 1 caja de jabón, 2 cientos de lejía, golosinas y 2 cajas de huevo.

Irma se siente muy tranquila y feliz porque sus sueños se están haciendo realidad puede manejar su negocio de manera independiente y al mismo tiempo ayudar a su familia en los gastos, gracias al apoyo que le brinda Manuela Ramos.

loans.use: Compra de abarrotes (arroz, azúcar, aceite, etc)

loans.name: Irma

texts.es:
La señora Irma  pertenece al Banco Comunal Solidaridad, vive en Jr. Maya de Britto 651, del Distrito de Calleria  del Departamento de Ucayali. Tiene 47 años y es madre de cuatro hijos  menores de edad, su esposo es chofer (transportista). Gracias al primer préstamo recibido de Manuela Ramos de S/. 300 soles, Beatriz decide invertir en una pequeña bodega.

En la actualidad ella cuenta con una bodega instalada en su propia casa, la misma que atiende con el apoyo de sus hijos, se levanta a las 6 a.m. para abrir su negocio y atender a sus clientes hasta las 10 pm. Simultáneamente atiende los quehaceres del hogar.

Con éste préstamo de S/. 2,000 soles, el cual será pagado en 5 meses, comprará 2 sacos de arroz, 2 sacos de azúcar, 3 cajas de aceite, 2 cajas de leche, 3 paquetes de fideos, 5 cajas de gaseosas, 2 bolsas de detergentes, 1 caja de jabón, 2 cientos de lejía, golosinas y 2 cajas de huevo.

Irma se siente muy tranquila y feliz porque sus sueños se están haciendo realidad puede manejar su negocio de manera independiente y al mismo tiempo ayudar a su familia en los gastos, gracias al apoyo que le brinda Manuela Ramos.

loans.use: Compra de abarrotes (arroz, azúcar, aceite, etc)

loans.name: Irma

texts.es:
Irma belongs to a communal bank and lives in Calleria, in the Ucayali region of Peru. She's 47 years old and has four young children. Her husband is a chauffer. With her initial loan, she decided to start a small convenience store, which she currently runs out of her home with the help of her children. She rises at 6 a.m. to open the business and tend to customers, at the same time taking care of household chores.

With the $700 loan, which she plans to repay in five months, she will purchase rice, sugar, oil, milk, noodles, drinks, detergent, soap, bleach, snacks and eggs.

Irma feels very calm and happy because her dreams are becoming reality. She can run her business independently and at the same time help her family with expenses, thanks to the support of Kiva partner Manuela Ramos.

Translated from Spanish by Marty Greenstein, Kiva Volunteer

La señora Irma pertenece al Banco Comunal Solidaridad, vive en Jr. Maya de Britto 651, del Distrito de Calleria del Departamento de Ucayali. Tiene 47 años y es madre de cuatro hijos menores de edad, su esposo es chofer (transportista). Gracias al primer préstamo recibido de Manuela Ramos de S/. 300 soles, Beatriz decide invertir en una pequeña bodega. En la actualidad ella cuenta con una bodega instalada en su propia casa, la misma que atiende con el apoyo de sus hijos, se levanta a las 6 a.m. para abrir su negocio y atender a sus clientes hasta las 10 pm. Simultáneamente atiende los quehaceres del hogar. Con éste préstamo de S/. 2,000 soles, el cual será pagado en 5 meses, comprará 2 sacos de arroz, 2 sacos de azúcar, 3 cajas de aceite, 2 cajas de leche, 3 paquetes de fideos, 5 cajas de gaseosas, 2 bolsas de detergentes, 1 caja de jabón, 2 cientos de lejía, golosinas y 2 cajas de huevo. Irma se siente muy tranquila y feliz porque sus sueños se están haciendo realidad puede manejar su negocio de manera independiente y al mismo tiempo ayudar a su familia en los gastos, gracias al apoyo que le brinda Manuela Ramos.

loans.use: Purchase grocery supplies (rice, sugar, oil, etc.)

loans.name: Eulogia Marbelì

texts.es:
Eulogia Marbeli R. Velasquez is a business woman in the main market in Chichigalpa, is married and has the responsibility to support two children in high school. Her business has been selling clothing since last year. She tells us that she had to start her business because her husband emigrated to the United States and while she waited for him to establish himself she needed to start the business. Today her husband helps her but is is not enough because the work that he has does not pay much for what he does.

Miss Eulogia has been working with CEPRODEL since last year and she feels very satisfied with the credit that has been granted to her and always at the right time, helping to fill the needs of her business and finally to keep her customers happy on a daily basis. She has a history of 3 loans to her name. Her greatest need now is to purchase clothing for resale in her neighbourhood.

Translated from Spanish by Erika Lindig, Kiva Volunteer.

Eulogia Marbeli R. V. es comerciante del mercado municipal de Chichigalpa, casada y con la responsabilidad de dos hijos en secundaria. Su negocio ha sido la venta de ropa desde hace un año. Nos cuenta que tuvo que poner este negocio porque su esposo emigró a los Estados Unidos de Norteamérica y ella para esperar que él se estabilizara en ese país tuvo que poner este negocio, hoy en día su esposo le ayuda pero no lo suficiente porque el trabajo que el tiene no gana mucho por lo que esta iniciando en el negocio.

Doña Eulogia trabaja con CEPRODEL desde hace 1 años y se siente muy satisfecha con los créditos otorgados pues les han sido brindados en el momento oportuno, ayudando a sí a suplir las necesidades del negocio y satisfacer a diario a su clientela. Ella tiene un record de 3 créditos. Su necesidad mayor en este momento es la compra de la ropa para luego comercializarla en el sector de su localidad.

loans.use: Purchase clothing

loans.name: Juana

texts.es:
Juana belongs to a communal bank and lives in Yarina Cocha in the Ucayali region of Peru. She's 35 years old and has two young children who are still dependant on her. Her husband is a logger. With her initial loan, Juana decided to invest in the purchase of clothing to resell, and she currently runs the business out of her home. She rises at 6 a.m. to work on household tasks before leaving in the afternoons to deliver her merchandise to her customers.

With the $425 loan, which she plans to repay in five months, Juana will purchase clothing for men, women and children, as well as undergarments, belts, stockings and other items.

Juana has become a hard-working woman dedicated to getting ahead for the well being of her children. She is very happy and wishes to continue moving up in life, always with thanks to God and her lenders, Kiva partner Manuela Ramos.

Translated from Spanish by Marty Greenstein, Kiva Volunteer

La señora Juana pertenece al Banco Comunal Las Paikanas, vive en el AA. HH. Violeta Correa Mz. A Lt. 18 del Distrito de Yarina Cocha del Departamento de Ucayali. Tiene 35 años y es madre de 2 hijos menores de edad que aun dependen de ella, es casada, su esposo se dedica a la extracción de la madera. Juana con el primer préstamo recibido de Manuela Ramos de S/.300 decide invertir en compra de prendas de vestir. En la actualidad ella continúa con el negocio de venta de ropas a domicilio, se levanta a las 6 a.m. para realizar las actividades del hogar para luego en las tardes salir a repartir la mercadería a sus clientes. Con éste préstamo de S/. 1,200 soles el cual será pagado en 5 meses, ella comprará ropa para damas, caballeros y niños, ropa interior, correas, medias, etc. Juana se volvió una mujer trabajadora, empeñosa y deseosa de salir adelante por el bienestar de sus hijos, esta muy feliz y desea seguir surgiendo en la vida, siempre dando gracias a Dios y a Manuela Ramos.

loans.use: Purchase clothing to sell.

loans.name: Keyli

texts.es:
Keyli belongs to a communal bank and lives in Yarina Cocha, in the Ucayali region of Peru. She's 44 years old and has three children, two who are grown and one who is still dependant on her. Her husband is a motorized rickshaw driver. With her initial loan Keyli decided to start her own sewing shop, which she currently runs out of her own home. She rises at 6 a.m. to make breakfast for her son and husband and then goes to work making the dresses her customers order.

With the $450 loan, which she plans to repay in five months, Keyli will purchase wood, nails, bars, cement, sand and other building supplies to make improvements on her shop.

Keyli is happy to belong to Kiva partner Manuela Ramos and of having started her own business. It makes her feel more independent, and she's grateful to all the people who always support her in reaching her goals.

Translated from Spanish by Marty Greenstein, Kiva Volunteer

La señora Keily pertenece al Banco Comunal Nuestra Señora del Carmen, vive en el Psj La Lupuna Mz. G Lt. 9, del Distrito de Yarina Cocha del departamento de Ucayali. Tiene 44 años y es madre de tres hijos, dos ya son independientes y uno aun depende de ella, su esposo es motocarrista. Gracias al primer préstamo recibido de Manuela Ramos de S/. 300 soles, Keyli decide implementar su taller de costura. En la actualidad ella continúa con el taller de costura instalado en su propio domicilio, se levanta a las 6 a.m. para hacer el desayuno de su hijo y su esposo y luego se dedica a coser las prendas que le encargan sus clientes. Con éste préstamo de S/. 1,300 soles, el cual será pagado en 5 meses, ella comprará maderas, clavos, listones, calaminas, cemento, arena, ripio, etc. para arreglar el ambiente donde funciona su taller. Keyli está feliz por pertenecer a Manuela Ramos, de haber puesto su propio negocio y se siente más independiente y esta muy agradecida con todas las personas que siempre la apoyaron para la realización de sus metas.

loans.use: Purchase building materials to make improvements on sewing shop (wood, nails, cement, etc.)

loans.name: Francisca Eufemia

texts.es:
Francisca Eufemia S. Navarette is a woman is dedicated to her business in beef meat sales, and has been running the business for the last 17 years. She tells us that 17 years ago she was widowed and given this situation she started her business to be able to support her family.

With a great deal of difficulty she has been able to make her business a success and has been able to support her family. Her major need is to purchase beef meat for resale, and it is for this reason that she seeks the help Ceprodel that has given her credit since last year. She feels very satisfied with the credit that has been granted to her and always at the right time, helping her to fill her business' requirements and provide what her clients need every day.

Translated from Spanish by Erika Lindig, Kiva Volunteer.

Francisca Eufemia S. N. es una dama que se dedica al negocio de venta de carne de res, tiene 17 años de tener este negocio, nos cuenta desde hace 17 años quedo viuda y por este motivo inicia este negocio para poder seguir manteniendo a su familia.

Con muchas dificultades ha logrado salir adelante en el negocio y ha podido mantener su núcleo familiar. Su mayor necesidad es la compra de la carne de res para su debida comercialización, por esta razón es que acude a Ceprodel quien desde hace 1 año ha recibido créditos de manera que hoy en día se siente muy satisfecha con los créditos otorgados ya que les han sido brindados en el momento oportuno, ayudándole así a suplir las necesidades del negocio y satisfacer a diario a su clientela.

loans.use: Purchase of meat

loans.name: Leyla Marice

texts.es:
Leyla belongs to a communal bank and lives in Calleria in the Ucayali region of Peru. She's 42 years old and has five young children. Her husband is a construction worker. With her initial loan, Leyla decided to invest in the purchase of a motorized rickshaw. She currently has two and has two drivers to operate them while she runs the business.

With the $700 loan, which Leyla plans to repay in five months, she will purchase another rickshaw and perform maintenance on her other two to keep them in good condition.

Leyla feels satisfied because she makes her own income without exhausting herself and has more time to spend with her children and take care of her home. She's glad she belongs to Kiva lending partner Manuela Ramos.

Translated from Spanish by Marty Greenstein, Kiva Volunteer

La señora Leyla pertenece al Banco Comunal Solidaridad, vive en Psj Contamana 148, del Distrito de Calleria, del Departamento de Ucayali. Tiene 42 años y es madre de 5 hijos menores de edad, su esposo es albañil. Gracias al primer préstamo recibido de Manuela Ramos de S/. 300 soles, Leyla decide invertir en la compra de un motocarro. En la actualidad ella cuenta con 2 motocarros, tiene 2 personas a su cargo quienes trabajan en las motos pues ella se encarga de la administración de las mismas. Con éste préstamo de S/. 2,000 soles, el cual será pagado en 5 meses, ella comprará un motocarro e invertirá en el mantenimiento de sus otros dos motocarros. Leyla se siente conforme porque tiene sus ingresos propios sin necesidad de esforzarse mucho y tiene mas tiempo para pasar con sus hijos y dedicarse a su hogar. Se siente contenta de pertenecer a la familia de Manuela Ramos.

loans.use: Purchase a motorized rickshaw and make repairs on two others.

loans.name: Margarita

texts.es:
Margarita belongs to a communal bank and lives in Manantay, in the Ucayali region of Peru. She's 45 years old and has three young children. She's married, and her husband is a farmer. She started her banana-selling business with a small loan.

Margarita currently has a sales post for her fruit on the sidewalk in front of her home and has a motorcized rickshaw to help her business. She rises at 5 a.m. to make her way to the port and purchase bananas at wholesale and takes them home to sell to her customers. She spends the afternoons with her children.

With the $425 loan, which she plans to repay in five months, Margarita will purchase various bunches of bananas, green and ripened, but the majority of the money will go toward maintenance on her motorcoach. She is happy because her business is growing by the day thanks to her hard work and constant motivation, her three children. She is very grateful for all the support from Kiva partner Manuela Ramos and its lenders.

Translated from Spanish by Marty Greenstein, Kiva Volunteer

La señora Margarita pertenece al banco comunal Nuestra Señora del Carmen, vive en el Asentamiento Humano Roca Fuerte Mz. 32 Lt. 5, del Distrito de Manantay del departamento de Ucayali. Tiene 45 años y es madre de 3 hijos menores de edad, es casada y su esposo es agricultor. Margarita, con el primer préstamo recibido de Manuela Ramos de S/. 300 soles decidió invertir en compra y venta de plátano (fruta). En la actualidad ella cuenta con un puesto de venta de plátano en la vereda de su casa, y un motocarro, el mismo que también le genera ingresos. Se levanta a las 5 a.m. para dirigirse al puerto a comprar plátano al por mayor para así poder llevar a su hogar y venderlos a sus clientes y por las tardes se dedica a sus hijos. Con éste préstamo de S/. 1,200 soels, el cual será pagado en 5 meses, ella comprará varios racimos de plátanos entre verdes y maduros, pero la gran mayoría del préstamo lo invertirá en el mantenimiento de su motocarro. Margarita esta feliz porque su negocio crece día a día gracias a todo el esfuerzo y las ganas que le pone y sobre todo por sus tres razones mas importantes que son sus hijos y está muy agradecida a todo el apoyo brindado por Manuela Ramos y a sus promotoras.

loans.use: Purchase bananas to sell and make repairs on motorized rickshaw.

loans.name: Milka

texts.es:
Ms. Milka belongs to the “Solidaridad” Communal Bank and lives in Jr. Oscar R. Benavides 234 of the Calleria district in the Ucayali area. She is 38 years old and single. She decided to invest the first loan of 300 soles received from Manuela Ramos in the purchase of a motorcycle taxi, presently driven by an employee hired by her.

She gets up at 6 am daily to to tend to the household chores and in the afternoon she learns crafts.

With the current loan of 1000 soles, to be repaid in five months, she will purchase accident insurance and defray the costs of the taxi's operation permit.

Milka is very happy, her motorcycle taxi is generating a good income and she feels more independent. With the support of Manuela Ramos, she hopes to buy another taxi.

Translated from Spanish by Leticia Britos, Kiva Volunteer.

La señora Milka pertenece al Banco Comunal Solidaridad, vive en Jr. Oscar R. Benavides 234 del Distrito de Calleria del Departamento de Ucayali. Tiene 38 años y es soltera. Milka, con el primer préstamo recibido de Manuela Ramos de S/.300 soles, decide invertir en la compra de un motocarro.

En la actualidad ella cuenta con un motocarro y tiene a su cargo una persona quien maneja el motocarro. Se levanta a las 6 a.m. para dedicarse a los quehaceres domésticos y en las tardes se dedica a estudiar manualidades.

Con éste préstamo de S/. 1,000 soles, el cual será pagado en 5 meses, comprará un seguro contra accidentes y cubrirá los gastos para los trámites de la tarjeta de circulación del motocarro.

Milka se encuentra muy feliz, su motocarro le esta dando buenos ingresos económicos, se siente más independiente y espera poder comprar otro motocarro, contando con el apoyo de Manuela Ramos.

loans.use: Purchase of accidents insurance and payment of taxi's operation permit.

loans.name: Genoveva Del Socorro

texts.es:
Genoveva R. sells fruit in the municipal market of Chichigalpa. She says that she began her business after her husband’s passing, when she realized that her family would need income. Furthermore, she incurred a large debt due to her husband’s funeral expenses.

Mrs. R. currently lives with her daughter who has a 3-year-old daughter of her own. She does everything possible in order for her daughter to have everything she needs, which is why she has been working with CEPRODEL for 3 years. She is very satisfied with her past loans, since she has been able to buy fruit and cover the expenses of her humble home with those loans. She has obtained a total of 22 loans.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Casian, Kiva Volunteer.

El negocio de Genoveva R. es la venta de frutas en el mercado municipal de Chichigalpa. Según dice, el negocio lo comienza cuando su esposo fallece y se da cuenta que el dinero en el núcleo familiar hacía mucha falta, además que tenía que pagar muchos gastos que le habían quedado del entierro del su esposo.

Doña Genoveva es una señora que actualmente vive sola, la acompaña una hija la cual tiene una niña de tres años, por quien dice hacer todo lo posible para que a ella no le falte nada, por eso ella trabaja con CEPRODEL desde hace 3 años y se siente muy satisfecha con los créditos otorgados por el motivo de que los ha utilizado para la compra de las frutas y además para los gastos de su humilde hogar. Ella tiene un record de 22 créditos.

loans.use: Purchase of fruit

loans.name: Sally Shalin

texts.es:
Ms. Sally belongs to the “Guadalupe” Communal Bank and lives in Av Colonización 682, Calleria district of the Ucayali area. She is 27 years old, married and mother of two small children. Her husband is a motorcycle-taxi driver. With the first loan received from Manuela Ramos of 300 soles she invested in the purchase of a motorcycle taxi.

She presently owns three taxis. Her husband drives one of them and she hires drivers for the other two. She gets up at 7 am daily to tend to the household chores.

With the current loan of 1000 soles, to be repaid in five months, she will be able to give proper maintenance to her motorcycles.

According to Sally, she is doing very well, as the money she collects from her drivers is enough to pay her monthly bills timely and to support her children's education, which gives her tranquility and stability. The support received from Manuela Ramos is very important to her and she is very grateful for it.

Translated from Spanish by Leticia Britos, Kiva Volunteer.

La señora Sally pertenece al Banco Comunal Guadalupe, vive en la Av Colonización 682, del Distrito de Calleria del Departamento de Ucayali. Tiene 27 años y es madre de 2 hijos que aún son menores de edad, es casada y su esposo es motocarrista (transportista). Sally, con el primer préstamo recibido de Manuela Ramos de S/. 300 soles, decide invertir en la compra de un motocarro.

En la actualidad ella cuenta con 3 motocarros, en uno de ellos trabaja el esposo, y además tiene 2 choferes a su cargo. Ella se levanta a las 7 a.m. para dedicarse a los quehaceres del hogar.

Con éste préstamo de S/. 1,000 soles, el cual será pagado en 5 meses, podrá dar mantenimiento a sus motocarros.

Sally manifiesta que todo le va muy bien, ya que el dinero que le entregan sus choferes le alcanza para pagar puntualmente sus mensualidades y para apoyar en la educación de sus hijos, lo que le permite gozar de tranquilidad y estabilidad. Para ella es muy importante el apoyo que le brinda Manuela Ramos y esta muy agradecida.

loans.use: Motorcycle taxis maintenance.

loans.name: Tomasa

texts.es:
Ms. Tomasa belongs to the “Nuevo Horizonte” Communal Bank and lives in Jr. Cusco Mz. H Lt. 6 of the Calleria district in the Ucayali department. She is 46 years old, married and mother of two little children. Her husband is an administrator. With the first loan received from Manuela Ramos of 300 soles she started her sheet sewing shop.

She is presently running her shop and has several overlockers. She gets up daily at 6am to make breakfast for her kids and husband, to then work in the manufacture of sheets. In order to meet the demands of her clients, she often works until very late at night.

With the current loan of 1000 soles, to be repaid in five months, she will buy fabrics, elastic, threads, needles, silk lace, as well as give maintenance to her overlock machines, which are her work tools.

Tomasa has greater independence and feels calmer. Furthermore, her family is very happy for her and for all the achievements she has attained thanks to the support received from Manuela Ramos.

Translated from Spanish by Leticia Britos, Kiva Volunteer.

La señora Tomasa pertenece al Banco Comunal Nuevo Horizonte, vive en Jr. Cusco Mz. H Lt. 6 del Distrito de Calleria del Departamento de Ucayali. Tiene 46 años y es madre de 2 hijos menores de edad, es casada y su esposo es administrador. Tomasa, con el primer préstamo recibido de Manuela Ramos de S/. 300 soles decide implementar su taller de costura de sábanas.

En la actualidad ella continúa con el taller, cuenta con varias remalladoras, se levanta a las 6 a.m. para preparar el desayuno de sus hijos y su esposo, luego se dedica a la confección de las sábanas, pues a diario tiene que cumplir con el pedido de sus clientes, muchas veces se queda hasta tardes horas de la noche para acabar con los pedidos.

Con este préstamo de S/. 1,000 soles, el cual será pagado en 5 meses, ella comprará telas, elásticos, hilos, blondas, agujas, además de dar mantenimiento a su máquina remalladora, que es su herramienta de trabajo.

Tomasa es más independiente, se siente más tranquila, su familia esta muy feliz por ella y por todo los logros que está alcanzando gracias al apoyo de Manuela Ramos.

loans.use: Purchase of materials (fabrics, elastics, threads, needles, etc).

loans.name: Viviana

texts.es:
Ms. Viviana belongs to “Las Paikanas” Communal Bank and lives in Miraflores Av. Mz. C Lt. 10 of the Yarina Cocha district in the Ucayali department. She is 36 years old, married and has four children, who are her dependants. Her husband is a merchant. With the first loan of 300 soles received from Manuela Ramos, she decided to set up a business selling clothes and shoes.

She is presently running her business, selling clothes and shoes for women, men and children. She gets up at 6 am every day to go to her sales stand, where she works until 10 pm. With this loan of 1200 soles, to be repaid in five months, she will buy 120 shoe pairs, 144 imported sneakers, 24 shirts, etc.

According to Viviana, the support received from Manuela Ramos is very important, as she is able to work independently, tend for herself and support her children in every aspect.

Translated from Spanish by Leticia Britos, Kiva Volunteer.

La señora Viviana pertenece al Banco Comunal Las Paikanas y vive en la Av. Miraflores. Mz. C Lt. 10 del Distrito de Yarina Cocha del Departamento de Ucayali. Tiene 36 años, casada y madre de 4 hijos menores de edad que aún dependen de ella. Su esposo es comerciante. Viviana, con el primer préstamo recibido de Manuela Ramos de S/. 300 soles, decidió implementar su negocio de ropas y zapatos.

En la actualidad ella continúa con el negocio de zapatos y ropas para damas, caballeros y niños, levantándose a las 6 a.m. para dirigirse a su puesto de venta, que atiende todos los días hasta las 10 p.m. Con éste préstamo de S/. 1200 soles, el cual será pagado en 5 meses, ella comprará 10 docenas de zapatos, 12 pares de zapatillas importadas, 2 docenas de camisas, etc.

Viviana nos dice que el apoyo que le brinda Manuela Ramos es muy importante porque puede trabajar independientemente, valerse por si misma y apoyar a sus hijos en todo aspecto y salir adelante.

loans.use: Purchase of shoes, sneakers and shirts.

loans.name: Soraida Katti

texts.en:
Soraida is the owner of one of the most famous grocery stores in Lambedera, in the community of Yamasá. Everyday, people in the neighborhood go to her store to purchase a wiD. range of products such as rice, milk, chocolate, juices, alcoholic drinks, and many other basic foodstuffs.

Soraida has been running her store for more than ten years. Soraida is married and has three sons aged of two, eight and ten years old. The two elder attend school.

The grocery store is the main source of income for the family, and through the business, she is supporting the studies of her sons. This determined businesswoman is requesting a loan to stock up the store since supplies are running low and she has to satisfy her customers’ needs.

loans.use: To restock a grocery store in order to face high demand from customers.

loans.name: Hoeur

texts.en: Mrs. Hoeur C., 36, is a mother of three children and lives in Siem Reap province, Cambodia. She works as a broker purchasing watermelons from the growers and reselling them to the people in her area, making on average around $5 each day of profit. Her husband is a soldier and earns only $3 each day in revenue. C. will use this loan to reinvest in her business and the leftover money will be used to renovate her house to protect it from flooding during the rainy season.

loans.use: To reinvest in her business.

loans.name: Dy

texts.en: Mrs. Dy S., 35, is married and lives with her husband in Siem Reap province, Cambodia. She runs a stand selling fish to the people in her community and generally makes on average around $2 each day in revenue. Her husband works selling charcoal and wood, making around $2 each day of profit. Mrs. Dy S. hopes to use this loan to expand her inventory by purchasing more fish to meet her growing customer demand.

loans.use: To expand her inventory by purchasing more fish to meet her growing customer demand.

loans.name: Lim

texts.en: Mrs. Lim Y., 42, is a mother of four children and lives with her husband in Siem Reap province, Cambodia. She works as a housewife cooking food for her family, so the income generation is handled by her husband who works as a motor-taxi driver and generally makes around $3 each day in revenue. Lim Y. has four children. One of them works driving a Tuk-Tuk to transport passengers; another one is unemployed; and the rest are enrolled in school. Lim Y. has applied for a loan to purchase a motorcycle for her unemployed son to operate a motor-taxi business. With the help of the loan, she believes it will enable her to raise her standard of living.

loans.use: To purchase a motorcycle for her unemployed son to operate a motor-taxi business

loans.name: Sin

texts.en: Mrs. Sin Y., 31, runs a stand at home selling a variety of food to the people in her area, making around $5 each day in revenue. Her husband works driving a motorcycle, with a trailer attached, for transporting passengers in his area, and he can generally make about $5 each day. Furthermore, Mrs. Sin Y. has four under school-aged children and would like a loan to expand her grocery stand by purchasing more products to meet her growing customer demand.

loans.use: To expand her grocery stand by purchasing more products to meet her growing customer demand.

loans.name: Thorn

texts.en: Mrs. Thorn D., 23, is married with one little kid and lives in a part of Siem Reap province, Cambodia. To make her living, she works raising pigs and reselling them to her nearby butcher, making on average around $2 each day. Her husband works charging various kinds of batteries for the people in his area, earning around $2 per day of profit. Thorn D. would like to use this loan to expand her livestock of pigs in order to increase her income.

loans.use: To expand her livestock of pigs to increase her income.

loans.name: Choam

texts.en: Mrs. Choam S., 51, is a mother of four children and lives with her husband in a part of Siem Reap province, Cambodia. She works on her farm growing rice, while her husband works as an electrician, making collectively around $7 each day. Also, two of her children work as electricians, one is a student, and one is unemployed. Choam S. hopes to use this loan to purchase a hand-tractor to plow their farm.  This will make her farming work easier, faster, and more effective.

loans.use: To purchase a hand-tractor to plow their farm

loans.name: Ek

texts.en: Mrs. Ek S., 39, is a mother of seven children and lives with her husband in a part of Siem Reap province, Cambodia. She and her husband sell pork and chicken at a busy market, earning collectively between $8 to $10/day in revenue. One of her children works grinding rice crops and typically earns $50 each month and the rest of are students. Mrs. Ek S. hopes to use this loan to reinvest in her business and to renovate her house to protect it from flooding during the rainy season.

loans.use: To reinvest in her business and renovate her house to protect against flooding

loans.name: Phoak

texts.en: Mrs. Phoak N., 26, is married and lives with her husband, her parents, and two nephews in a part of Siem Reap province, Cambodia. She and her husband work as massagers, together making around $8 each day in revenue. Mrs. Phoak N. hopes to use this loan to purchase a motorcycle to use for her family’s transportation. In the future, she would like to save a lot of money to open a grocery store in her area.

loans.use: To purchase a motorcycle for her family’s transportation.

loans.name: Farogat

texts.en:
N. Farogat is 28 years old and is married with four children.

Farogat has been running her business already for 10 years. She is selling the stock in one of the local markets. Farogat’s business is quite successful which allows her to receive loans by IMON multiple times. She also is paying all the loans in a timely manner. At the same time, the income is sufficient for supporting the family and improving the living conditions.

Today, Farogat requests 3400.00 Somoi (1000.00 US Dollars) for the term of 12 months. She plans to spend the loan to increase the amount of working capital. The generated income will be used for purchasing the new trading place for her husband. Farogat promises to pay back the loan in time.

loans.use: To incrase the working capital and use the generated income to purchase the trading place for the husband.

loans.name: Zufar

texts.en:
A. Zufar is 53 years old. He has very large family. Together with his wife, Zufar is raising seven children.

For more than 20 years, Zufar has been engaged in the processing of agricultural products. He cracks and cleans the walnuts, almonds and pistachio. This is extremely labor-intensive and time-consuming; that is why the entire family helps Zufar. The nuts are delivered by Zufar from Kyrgyzstan. After cleaning all the nuts, they are ready for sales. As a rule, Zufar sells them to people who export the product to Russia and other countries.

Now, Zufar wants to arrange the export of the nuts by himself. With this purpose in mind, he requests 2400.00 Somoni (700.00US Dollars) to pay all the necessary fees for arranging this. The term of the loan is 12 months. This is the second loan for Zufar, and he had already recommended himself as a reliable client.

loans.use: To pay the fee for export of cracked and cleaned walnuts, almond, and pistachio

loans.name: Iyan

texts.en: Iyan, 20, is the mother of a son, age 1. She sells snacks, beverages, etc., at her food stall earning $10 a day, while her husband, S., sells waste materials and earns $10 a week. She is asking for a loan of $100 to buy more goods for her stall. She is a member of MBK and is willing to repay this loan within a period of 12 months.

loans.use: To buy more goods for her stall

loans.name: Arobian

texts.en: Arobian, 31, is the mother of 4 children. She sells clothing, fabric, and sheets and earns $30 a week, while her husband, S., sells waste (salvaged) materials and earns $20 a week. She requests a loan of $75 to expand her business, and as a member of MBK she agrees to repay this loan within a period of 12 months.

loans.use: Business expansion

loans.name: Maryam

texts.en: Maryam, 18, is the mother of 9-year-old son. She sells snacks, crispy chips, etc., and earn $7 a day, while her husband, M., does not have any job. She is asking for a loan of $75 to buy more goods. She is a member of MBK and willing to repay this loan within a period of 12 months.

loans.use: To buy more goods

loans.name: Nasiah

texts.en: Nasiah, 28, is the mother of 2 children who sells soap at her house, earning $3 a day. Her husband, A., is giving people rides on his motorcycle taxi and earning $3 a day. She is asking for a loan of $75 to add to her business captial, and as a member of MBK she is willing to repay this loan within a period of 12 months.

loans.use: Add her business capital

loans.name: Teresa Quiasse

texts.pt:
Teresa Quiasse T. lives in the Trevo district. She is married and a mother of 3 children. Her business is selling drinks and sodas in Matola Rio at Kilometer 16. She entered the program on September 21, 2006 and is now in the 4th loan cycle. She is asking for $425.00US for 4 months, and she intends to invest the money in her business.

Translated from Portuguese by Jared Wandry, Kiva Volunteer

Teresa Quiasse T. residente no bairro trevo vive maritalmente é mãe de 3 filhos negociante vende bebidas e ferigerantes tem o seu negocio na Matola Rio km 16 entrou no programa a 21/09/06 agora esta no 4º ciclo vai tomar o valor de 10000 mt para pagar em 4 meses.o valor é para investir no negocio

loans.use: Increase inventory

loans.name: Acih

texts.en: Acih, 35, the mother of 3 children, and her husband, A., are selling noodles at their wagon. They could earn $15 a day. She is asking for a loan of $75 to expand her business, and as a member of MBK she is willing to repay this loan within a period of 12 months.

loans.name: Runyenjes Community Based Distributors Group

texts.en: Runyenjes CBD (community-based distributors) group with 40 registered members was started in 1996 with the mission to distribute contraceptives, provide health education, and go on home visits. Meeting monthly on the hospital grounds, they share their experiences and problems in the field and try to find solutions. They are being helped by the Runyenjes Hospital staff that has provided information about family planning issues and also supplied them with contraceptives. Other partners of the Runyenjes group include the Ministry of Health and numerous other organizations, such as the Chogoria Hospital CBD. In 2001, Kisumu Medical & Education Trust sponsored updates and trainings on a number of key issues, including family planning, the Community Based Abortion Care Project (COBAC), as well as first-aid and home-based care. KMET have been supplying the group with contraceptives as well as Nutriflour which they distribute to the community. The community truly appreciates the services KMET is offering through their partnerships. KMET has also empowered the group's members through its loans. Consequently, Runyenjes group's members have improved their living standards and health status as well as the severity of poverty in the community. The members are motivated and have been able to reach more clients with family planning services. The area where the group provides its services is agriculturally rich, and the main economic activity and source of income is farming. It is the case also for the members of Runyenjes group - 90% of them grow various crops ranging from tea and coffee, to maize and bananas. The produce, especially bananas grown in large amounts, is transported to Nairobi, 200 km away. A lot of money is spent on hiring a truck to transport the produce to the market for sale. The Runyenjes group is therefore asking for a loan of US$5,000 to help them pay for part of the distribution van cost so as to make product distribution easier and less costly.

loans.use: Purchase of a van to help transport farm produce to the market

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Kisumu Medical & Education Trust (K-MET) - Oct 24, 2008)

Sincerely,
Isadora Tang, Kiva Fellow, Cambodia

About SELFINA

SELFINA is engaged in economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through leasing and leaseback facility as a practical way to achieve the economic and social emancipation of women.

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. Customs and traditions in Tanzania normally make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed not-creditworthy by financial institutions as they lack tangible collateral assets. This leads to poor financial support; hence, poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes.

SELFINA buys and leases equipment to women. Where a client needs working capital SELFINA buys equipment from said client, extending a loan to her, then leasing back the same equipment – a process called a sale and leaseback arrangement.

loans.use: To purchase additional stocks of rice in bulk.

loans.name: Pendo

texts.en:
Mambo from Mwanza, Tanzania! This is 31 year-old Pendo J.. She is married with three children, aged 8, 10, and 12. In 2007, Pendo established a poultry business, and now requires a loan of $350 in order to purchase more chicks to raise and sell. She thanks you for your support.

Raising kuku is a popular micro-business in Tanzania, especially amongst SELFINA clients. Kuku means chickens in Swahili, and raising them for sale is popular for a number of reasons. First, they require little start-up capital; you can start with one or two and either add to them as you go or wait for them to multiple naturally! Second, they require little space, so sometimes you can just let them run around in your garden or compound. Third, while they are growing they produce eggs, which can either be sold to provide a supplementary source of income, or eaten to provide a supplementary source of protein.

loans.use: To purchase more chicks to raise and sell.

loans.name: Jamila

texts.en:
Mambo from Mwanza, Tanzania! This is 30-year-old Jamila Zaidi. She is married with three children, aged 5, 7, and 10. In 2003 Jamila established a business selling used clothing and soap, and now requires a loan of $350 in order to purchase additional stock in bulk.

Second-hand clothes journey across the oceans from America and Europe, and are then washed, ironed and sold in bulk by wholesalers in Dar es Salaam and other major towns and cities in Tanzania to retailers who then re-wash and re-iron them for sale on the streets, in shops, and people's homes and gardens. These clothes are becoming increasingly popular, especially amongst the younger generation, because they are so cheap and because of the general appeal of anything western or modern. Many people argue that the popularity of the West’s cast-offs is damaging the local cloth and garment industry. There are many people who still appreciate the beauty of traditional Tanzanian dress; however the growing market in used clothing and its importance to many micro-entrepreneurs cannot be denied.

loans.use: To purchase additional stocks of used clothing and soap in bulk.

loans.name: Habiba

texts.en: Habiba is one of Microinvest’s most active clients. Her first loan was $ 100,which she spent on an expansion of her business. She bought new modern clothes of high quality from Bishkek,Kirgizistan. The clothes from this country are in good demand in local market and Habiba can sell her batch in short time. Due to loans from Microinvest she increased her working capital and attracted more clients. Today her customers like doing business with her, because she is very friendly and has a nice selection of items for sale. Currently she has applied for a loan to increase the number of warm clothes available in her shop during the winter season

loans.use: Business expansion.

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mambo from Mwanza, Tanzania! This is 51-year-old Mary M.. She is single with three children, aged 7, 13, and 15. Mary runs a livestock business, and requires a loan of $450 in order to purchase additional cows and poultry.

Raising kuku is a popular micro-business in Tanzania, especially amongst SELFINA clients. In fact, if you are a regular lender on Kiva.org, you may be tired of reading about kuku. Who or what are ‘kuku’, you may ask. Kuku means chickens in Swahili, and raising them for sale is popular for a number of reasons.

Firstly, they require little start-up capital: you can start with one or two and either add to them as you go or wait for them to multiply naturally! Secondly, they require little space, so sometimes you can just let them run around in your garden or compound. Thirdly, while they are growing they produce eggs, which can either be sold to provide a supplementary source of income, or eaten to provide a supplementary source of protein. I’m sure there are hundreds of other reasons why raising kuku is so popular (maybe they are friendlier than other animals? Prettier?), but this is all time and space will allow.

loans.use: To purchase additional cows and chickens.

texts.en:
Mambo from Mwanza, Tanzania! This is 27-year-old Bestina M.. She is married with three children, aged 3, 5, and 8. In 2005 Bestina established a business selling music cassettes, CDs and DVDs, and now requires a loan of $350 in order to expand her range of stock. She thanks you for your support.

About SELFINA
SELFINA is engaged in economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through leasing and leaseback facility as a practical way to achieve the economic and social emancipation of women.

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. Customs and traditions in Tanzania normally make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed not-creditworthy by financial institutions as they lack tangible collateral assets. This leads to poor financial support hence poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes.

SELFINA buys and leases equipment to women. Where a client needs working capital SELFINA buys equipment from said client, extending a loan to her, then leasing back the same equipment – a process called a sale and leaseback arrangement.

loans.use: To expand her range of music cassettes, CDs and DVDs.

loans.name: Zaman

texts.en: Mr. Zaman is a 31-year-old farmer who has one milk cow. He is married and has two children. He recently started selling diary products. When he started his business in 1999, he was selling meat in the Saatli bazaar. Zaman lives in in the southern Azerbaijani village of Mollavazi in the Saatli region. Zaman is going to purchase one milk cow to expand his dairy production and one calf to begin selling meat to the local bazaar trades. The estimated cost for one milk cow is $500 and for a calf is $200. He plans to pay the loan back in 12 months

loans.use: To buy calves

loans.name: Gulu C 2001(I) Group

texts.en:
This group has been together for one year and six months. Mary is 45 years old and married with five children. She runs a butcher shop. With the extra business profits, Mary intends to pay school fees for the children. Gertrude and Mary have piggery businesses. Specioza has grocery store.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To expand the butcher business

loans.name: Castro Francisco

texts.pt:
Castro Francisco C., ID number 110042523N, is single and just joined the credit program. He is requesting a loan of 7000MT to be repaid in 6 months. Castro will invest the funds on the construction of his house. He is a teacher

Translated from Portuguese by Mariana Komatsuzaki Fraga Kiva Volunteer.

Castro Francisco C., portador do BI nº 110042523N, solteiro esta a entrar no programa vai levar o valor de 7000 a pagar em 6 meses o valor e para investir na construção é trabalhador , é professor.

loans.use: Construction

loans.name: Shamo

texts.en:
Mr. Shamo is 37, married, with three children. He lives in the village of Saatli town in the south-central flat area of Azerbaijan Republic, in Caucasus region.
Shamo owns a herd of milk cows. Every day he sells milk to the local milk-processing shop. His children help him breed the cows in the nearby grazing area. The income from four cows is too low to support the family. That’s why Shamo applied to Norwegian Microcredit Saatli branch for a $500 loan, to buy one more pure-bred cow to make his monthly income higher. The price of a milk calf is $300, the cost of breeding is $100. The other $100 he plans to save for unexpected expenditures.

loans.use: To buy a cow

loans.name: Thai

texts.en: Mrs. Thai L. H., 31, is married with two little children and runs a stand selling foods and vegetables to the people in her area, making on average around $6 each day of profit. Lately, due her growing customer demand, L. H. has applied for a loan to purchase more grocery products to expand her inventory.

loans.use: To purchase more grocery products to expand her inventory.

loans.name: Gulu C 2001(Ii) Group

texts.en:
Aisha is married with two children. She has a retail shop business. She intends to use the extra busines profits to increase stock in the business and pay school fees for the children. Edith and Flavia both sell charcoal. Yudaya sells raw foods in the market and wans to use the loan to expand her business.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: Tadd in stock in the retail shop.

loans.name: Suriya's Group

texts.en:
"I am Suriya T.. I was born in Mian Chunnu , a small town, but later I moved to Multan, a mid-size city in Pakistan. I am the mother of nine: four girls and five boys. My son needs a loan to buy wood for our furniture manufacturing. Our business does well and generates decent profits. Earlier, with these profits, I constructed a house for my parents who are very poor and old.

I am a group leader of four other women. We are mutually responsible for each other’s loans, so if one does not repay others will pay for her. Farzana B. runs a boutique. Koser B. will invest the loan in their rug manufacturing. Shamim B. manufactures cloth on power looms."

loans.use: Buy wood for our furniture-making business

loans.name: Metrida

texts.en:
Mambo from Mwanza, Tanzania! This is 43-year-old Metrida M.. She is married with four children, ages 10, 14, 16, and 20, and has one other dependent, who is her niece. Metrida runs a poultry business, and requires a loan of $450 in order to purchase additional chicks to raise and sell.

Raising kuku is a popular micro-business in Tanzania, especially amongst SELFINA clients. In fact, if you are a regular lender on Kiva.org, you may be tired of reading about kuku. "Who or what are kuku?" you may ask. Kuku means chickens in Swahili, and raising them for sale is popular for a number of reasons. Firstly, they require little start-up capital. You can start with one or two and either add to them as you go or wait for them to multiply naturally! Secondly, they require little space, so sometimes you can just let them run around in your garden or compound. Thirdly, while they are growing they produce eggs, which can either be sold to provide a supplementary source of income or eaten to provide a supplementary source of protein. I’m sure there are hundreds of other reasons why raising kuku is so popular (maybe they are friendlier than other animals or prettier?), but this is all time and space will allow.

loans.use: To purchase additional chickens to raise and sell.

loans.name: Fatina

texts.en:

Fatina has already received and successfully repaid three loans from SELFINA, and now requires a loan of $450 in order to purchase additional materials and dyes. She thanks you for your support.

About SELFINA

SELFINA is engaged in economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through leasing and leaseback as a practical way to achieve the economic and social emancipation of women. SELFINA has taken a leading role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. Customs and traditions in Tanzania normally make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions as they lack tangible collateral assets. This leads to poor financial support, hence poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. SELFINA buys and leases equipment to women. Where a client needs working capital SELFINA buys equipment from said client, extending a loan to her, then leasing back the same equipment—a process called a sale and leaseback arrangement.

loans.use: To purchase additional weaving materials and dyes in bulk

loans.name: Im

texts.en: Mrs. Im S., 40, is a mother of four children in school, and works selling various kinds of vegetables to the people in her area, making on average of $4.50 each day in revenue. Her husband works on his plot of farmland growing crops and also driving a horse cart to transport passengers, earning typically about $2 each day. Mrs. Im S. hopes to use this loan to reinvest in her business and to buy another plot of farmland to expand her crops.

loans.use: To reinvest in her business and to buy another plot of farmland to expand her crops.

payments.comment:
Congratulations! Im Sary has fully repaid this Kiva loan early.

Thank you for your support of Cambodian entrepreneurs. Lenders like you allow entrepreneurs around the world access to low-interest loans to finance their small businesses and support their families.

We hope you will continue your support by reinvesting in another Kiva entrepreneur.

Sincerely,
Isadora Tang, Kiva Fellow, Cambodia

loans.name: Rukkiah's Group

texts.en:
"I am Rukkiah R. from Multan, Pakistan. I embroider clothes and I have been in this business for the last eight years. I plan to expand my business and with the future profits, I will buy a piece of land to build a house for my kids.

I would like to borrow in a group with my other group members. Hanifa B. needs loan for their used items business. Two other group members, Naseem B. and Wazira B., will expand their embroidery businesses with the loan. Shahnaz B. needs to buy a yarn machine for their business."

loans.use: Expand my embroidery business

loans.name: Im

texts.en: Mrs. Im D., 35, is a mother of three school-aged children and lives in a part of Kampong Cham province, Cambodia. She and her husband work as silversmiths, producing bracelets, earrings, rings, necklaces and various kinds of jewelries, making collectively around $9 each day of income. Mrs. Im D. has lately requested a loan to purchase more raw silver to increase the amount of products to meet growing customer demand.

loans.use: To purchase more raw silver to increase amount of products to meet growing customer demand.

loans.name: Identity

texts.en:
The entrepreneur is 30 years old. He has two children. One of them is studying in school. His wife has asthma, and she needs medical treatment all the time. He has a taxi, and he applied to borrow $1200 to purchase a new engine and some spare parts. He also wants to paint the car. He wants to increase his income and save for a better life for his family.

Disclaimer: This entrepreneur is from a volatile region where the security situation remains unsettled. Lenders to this business should be aware that this loan may represent a higher risk and accept this additional risk in making their loan.

Note: Personally identifiable attributes of this entrepreneur have been altered to protect him or her (i.e. blacking out portions of the entrepreneur in his/her picture, altering his/her first or last name, etc.).

loans.use: Purchase a new engine

Mambo from Mwanza, Tanzania! This is 48-year-old Agnes H.. She is married with five children, their ages between 17 and 29. In 2005 Agnes established a livestock business, and now requires a loan of $450 in order to expand her livestock to include poultry and the sale of eggs.

Raising kuku is a popular micro-business in Tanzania, especially amongst SELFINA clients. In fact, if you are a regular lender on Kiva.org, you may be tired of reading about kuku. "Who or what are kuku?" you may ask. Kuku means chickens in Swahili, and raising them for sale is popular for a number of reasons. Firstly, they require little start-up capital. You can start with one or two and either add to them as you go or wait for them to multiply naturally! Secondly, they require little space, so sometimes you can just let them run around in your garden or compound. Thirdly, while they are growing they produce eggs, which can either be sold to provide a supplementary source of income or eaten to provide a supplementary source of protein. I’m sure there are hundreds of other reasons why raising kuku is so popular (maybe they are friendlier than other animals or prettier?), but this is all time and space will allow.

loans.use: To expand her livestock business by purchasing chickens to raise and sell.

Mambo from Mwanza, Tanzania! This is 35-year-old Theopister M.. She is married with two children, ages 13 and 17. In 2002 Theopister established a shoes and clothing business, and now requires a loan of $875 in order to purchase additional stock in bulk. She thanks you for your support.

About SELFINA

SELFINA is engaged in economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through leasing and leaseback as a practical way to achieve the economic and social emancipation of women. SELFINA has taken a leading role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. Customs and traditions in Tanzania normally make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions as they lack tangible collateral assets. This leads to poor financial support, hence poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. SELFINA buys and leases equipment to women. Where a client needs working capital SELFINA buys equipment from said client, extending a loan to her, then leasing back the same equipment—a process called a sale and leaseback arrangement.

loans.use: To expand her range of clothing and shoes.

loans.name: Perpetua

texts.en:
Mambo from Mwanza, Tanzania! This is 43-year-old Perpetua M.. In 2007 Perpetua established a soft drink business, and now requires a loan of $350 in order to purchase additional stock in bulk.

It is said that Coca Cola is one of the most recognized symbols or ‘words’ in the world. And it’s true. Even in the most remote villages in Africa, there is usually some kind of beverage stand selling Coke, Fanta, and Guiness. (Pepsi has made it to most African capitals but not to the sticks, but I’m sure they’re working on it!) The hot weather makes soft drinks all the more appealing--heat is a very cheap marketing tool! All of which explains why selling soft drinks is such a popular venture, whether you’re the CEO of Coca Cola Ltd in the United States or a micro-entrepreneur in Tanzania!

loans.use: To purchase additional stock of soft drinks in bulk.

loans.name: Maria Claudina Lotes

texts.pt:
Maria Claudina Lotes B. lives with her husband and 5 children in Hulene-Maputo, Mozambique, where she is in the business of selling basic food products and beverages. She just joined the program and plans to use her first loan to increase the market's stock.

Translated from Portuguese by Aline Pereira, Kiva volunteer.

Maria Claudina Lotes B., portadora do BI nº 110577944Q, vive maritalmente tem 5 filhos esta a entrar no programa vai tomar o valor de 5000 a pagar em 5 meses o valor é para aplicar no negocio.

loans.use: To buy more food products to sell at her market

loans.name: Rahel

texts.en:
Mambo from Mwanza, Tanzania! This is 26-year-old Rahel D.. She is married with two children, ages 3 and 4. In 2003 Rahel established a business selling fish, and now requires a loan of $450 in order to purchase additional stocks of fish in bulk. She thanks you for your support.

About SELFINA
