En la actualidad continúa con la venta de gaseosas, chupetes, hielo, gelatina y agua mineral. Se levanta a las 7 a.m. para preparar su desayuno y estar pendiente de sus clientes para atenderlos durante todo el día.

Con el préstamo de S/. 1,700, el cual pagará en 5 meses, invertirá en la compra de 4 cajas de gaseosas y el resto lo irá invirtiendo poco a poco en gelatinas y demás bebidas.

Lizarda es una mujer luchadora y a pesar de su edad, tiene las energías para seguir adelante y valerse por si misma. Está muy agradecida por el apoyo que le brinda Manuela Ramos durante todo el tiempo que está con ellas.

loans.use:
To purchase carbonated beverages and other drinks

Compra de gaseosas y otros

loans.name: Betty Lely's Group

texts.en:
Fortunata, Filomena, and Betty have been members of the community bank “Dignidad” for 2 years, 4 months, and one year respectively.  Fortunata is the current president of her bank.  They all mentioned that they have learned a lot from the lessons on how to treat your children, self-esteem, punctuality, responsibility, and saving.
Fortunata is 39 years old, and is a single mother of one son.  Together with a friend she sells orange juice, which they make.  In addition, with her free time she cleans houses and hotels.  Fortunata dreams of owning a house, and her own hotel.
Filomena is forty, and is also a single mother.  She has two children.  Filomena has been selling plastic wares from a stand in Ayacucho for three years.  Before that she worked as a domestic servant, but thanks to her savings and loans she received she was able to start her own business.
Meanwhile Betty is thirty-seven.  She lives with her partner and four children.  Betty sells coca leaves, which are the medicinal plants cocaine can be made from.  She buys them in the markets of Ayacucho and travels several hours to the region of Huancavelica to sell them.
Fortunata, Filomena, and Betty each need loans of 400 soles (3 soles = $1), which they will invest in buying oranges, plastic wares, bags, and coca leaves.
They plan to use their savings to build a house, buy land, and to pay for their children’s education.  Their dreams are to have their own house, own a hotel, and that their children will be professionals.

loans.use: Fortunata, Filomena, and Betty each need loans of 400 soles (3 soles = $1), which they will invest in buying oranges, plastic wares, bags, and coca leaves.

loans.name: Noemi Esther

texts.es:
Noemí belongs to the Las Águilas community bank located on Jr. Leoncio Prado 237, Calleria, Ucayali. She is 68 years old, separated, and the mother of 7. Her children all currently live on their own, but continue to support their mother. With the first loan she received from Manuela Ramos totaling 300 sols, she decided to invest in a small restaurant.

Currently she owns a shop that makes and sells a variety of sandwiches throughout the region. She wakes up at 7 in the morning to make breakfast and then get to work.

With the loan valued at 1,300 sols ($450), to be paid back in 5 months, she will purchase 1 sack each of starch, rice and sugar, 5 crates of eggs, 1 box of oils, etc.

Noemí is happy to be healthy and to have received support from Manuela Ramos because they have allowed her to increase her labor capital and consequently improve her quality of life.

Translated from Spanish by Joanne Egnatchik, Kiva volunteer

La señora Noemí pertenece al banco comunal Las Águilas, ubicado en el Jr. Leoncio Prado 237, distrito de Calleria, departamento de Ucayali. Tiene 68 años, es separada y madre de 7 hijos, todos ya independientes, pero no dejan de apoyarla. Con el primer préstamo que recibió de Manuela Ramos de S/. 300 decide invertir en una pequeña bodega. En la actualidad cuenta con un negocio de preparación y venta de diferentes tipos de bocaditos de la región. Se levanta a las 7 de la mañana para preparar su desayuno y luego comienza con su trabajo. Con el préstamo de S/. 1,300, el cual pagará en 5 meses, invertirá en la compra de 1 saco de almidón, 1 saco de arroz, 1 saco de azúcar, 5 casilleros de huevos, 1 caja de aceites, etc. Noemí se siente contenta por la buena salud y por el apoyo que recibe de Manuela Ramos ya que ello le ha permitido ampliar su capital de trabajo y por ende mejorar su calidad de vida.

loans.use:
To purchase ingredients (starch, rice, sugar, eggs, etc.)

Compra de insumos (almidón, arroz, azúcar, huevos, etc)

loans.name: Rufina's Group

texts.en:
Rufina and Cirila have been members of the community bank “Dignidad” for four and five years respectively.  In the community bank they have learned how to invest their money, how to manage their business, to be responsible, respectful, and generous.  They mentioned how much they like having a savings account, and how much help the loans are for their businesses.

Rufina is 47 years old.  She is married and has four children.  Together with her husband Rufina buys cattle in the town of Luyanta, raises them, and then sells them at the Sunday market in San Juan Bautista.  In addition, Rufina buys pigs and butchers them for restaurants.

Cirila is 45 years old.  She is married and has five children.  Cirila sells coca leaves.  This is a medicinal herb that has many uses.  She buys the leaves in Ayacucho and travels several hours to sell it in the region of Huancavelica.  Sometimes she buys cheeses in Huancavelica and later sells them in her neighborhood.  

Rufina and Cirila need loans of 600 and 1000 soles, which they will invest in buying cattle and coca leaves.
They plan to use their savings to buy a motorcycle taxi, build a house, and pay their children’s school fees.  Rufina and Cirila dream of owning a home with all of the modern conveniences, that their children will be professionals, and that their businesses will continue to prosper.

loans.use: Rufina and Cirila need loans of 600 and 1000 soles, which they will invest in buying cattle and coca leaves.

loans.name: Olga

texts.es:
Mrs. Olga belongs to Banco Comunal Guadalupe, it is located at AA.HH 9 de octubre, Jr Huascar 102, Calleria district, Ucayali province. She is 55 years old, has 5 children who are all independent, married, and her husband is a merchant. With the first loan that she already received, she purchased soft drinks.

Currently, she sells bottles. She wakes up at 6:00am in order to get breakfast ready and have the rest of the day to work.

With the loan she requests, which she plans on paying back within 5 months, she will buy more bottles.

Olga shares with us that Manuela Ramos is of great help because through these loans she is able to keep her business. This way she can work independently and for this she is very grateful.

Translated from Spanish by Maria Peterson, Kiva Volunteer.

La señora Olga pertenece al banco comunal Guadalupe, ubicado en el AA.HH 9 de Octubre, Jr Huascar 102, distrito de Calleria, departamento de Ucayali. Tiene 55 años y es madre de 5 hijos, todos ya son independientes, es casada y su esposo es comerciante. Con el primer préstamo que recibió de Manuela Ramos de S/. 300 decide invertir en la venta de bebidas gaseosas. En la actualidad se dedica a la venta de botellas en su domicilio, se levanta a las 6 a.m. para preparar el desayuno y durante el día se dedica a su negocio. Con el préstamo de S/. 2,300, el cual pagará en 5 meses, invertirá en la compra de botellas. Olga manifiesta que Manuela Ramos es una gran ayuda porque mediante los préstamos le facilita poder mantener el negocio y así poder trabajar de manera independiente, por lo cual esta muy agradecida.

loans.use: Purchase of bottles

loans.name: Zoila

texts.es:
Zoila belongs to the Las Paikanas community bank located in AH, at Micaela Bastidas, Jr. 1ro de Mayo 250, District of Calleria, Deparment of Ucayali. She is 34 years old and the mother of two young children who are still dependent on her. She is married and her husband works in a glass factory. With the first 300 sols loan granted by Manuela Ramos, she decided to begin selling soft drinks.

She currently still sells carbonated beverages, ice and homemade popsicles.

With the loan valued at 1,000 sols, which she will repay in five months, she will purchase bags for the ice and popsicles, 1 box of milk and 10 boxes of soft drinks.

Zoila has become an enterprising woman who independently manages her own business, supports her family and finances her children’s education. She has shown that the support from Manuela Ramos has helped her to grow, to believe in herself and to do things she never thought possible; she is very proud of these achievements.

Translated from Spanish by Joanne Egnatchik, Kiva volunteer

La señora Zoila pertenece al banco comunal Las Paikanas, ubicado en el AA.HH. Micaela Bastidas, Jr. 1ro de Mayo 250, distrito de Calleria, departamento de Ucayali. Tiene 34 años y es madre de 2 hijos menores de edad que aún depende de ella, es casada y su esposo trabaja en una vidriería. Con el primer préstamo que recibió de Manuela Ramos de S/. 300 decide invertir en la venta de gaseosas.

En la actualidad continúa con la venta de bebidas gaseosas, hielos y elaboración de chupetes.

Con el préstamo de S/. 1,000, el cual pagará en 5 meses, comprará bolsas para hielo y chupetes, 1 caja de leche y 10 cajas de gaseosas.

Zoila se volvió una mujer emprendedora ya que maneja independientemente su propio negocio, aporta en su hogar y en la educación de sus hijos. Manifiesta que el apoyo brindado por Manuela Ramos la ayudó bastante a crecer y a creer en ella misma, a realizar cosas que no pensaba y se siente muy feliz por ello.

loans.use:
To purchase products (bags, milk, refreshments)

Compra de productos (bolsas, leche, gaseosas)

loans.name: Zoila Rosa

texts.es:
La señora Zoila  pertenece al Banco Comunal Cesar Vallejo,  ubicado en Av. Manco Cápac 273, del Distrito de Calleria  del Departamento de Ucayali. Tiene 62 años y es madre de 5 hijos, es casada, su esposo es almacenero,  Zoila con el primer préstamo  recibido de Manuela Ramos  de S/. 300 decide invertir en la inicial para la compra de un motocar. 

En la actualidad cuenta con un negocio de compra y venta de repuestos para motores en su casa, además posee un motocar que presta servicio de transporte .    
	
Con el préstamo de S/. 1,300, el cual pagará en 5 meses, invertirá en la compra de repuestos para motores chinos, repuestos para motores de aserraderos, y piladoras.     

Zoila se siente muy feliz y a pesar de su edad y de las dificultades que se le presentaron en la vida sigue saliendo adelante, creciendo con su negocio para el bienestar de su familia y además está  muy agradecida por el apoyo que le brinda Manuela Ramos.

loans.use: Compra de repuestos para motores de aserradores y piladoras

loans.name: Zoila Rosa

texts.es:
Mrs. Zolia is a member of the Community Bank Vallejo, located on Manco Capac Avenue #273, in the District of Calleria of the Ucayali Department. She is 62 years old and has 5 children. She is married and her husband runs a general store. With the funds from her first loan from Manuela Ramos of 300 Soles (about USD $100), Zolia was able to put a down payment on a purchase of a car.

Currently she has a business of buying and selling motor spare parts out of her home and also owns a car with which she provides transportation services. With the loan of 1,300 Soles or USD $450, which she will repay in 5 months, she will purchase spare parts for Chinese motors, spare parts for mill motors and peelers.

Zolia is very happy and in spite of the difficulties that she has encountered in her life, she continues to move forward, growing her business for the benefit of her family. She is also very thankful for the support that she has received from Manuela Ramos.

Translated from Spanish by Laura Bobbit, Kiva volunteer.

La señora Zoila pertenece al Banco Comunal Cesar Vallejo, ubicado en Av. Manco Cápac 273, del Distrito de Calleria del Departamento de Ucayali. Tiene 62 años y es madre de 5 hijos, es casada, su esposo es almacenero, Zoila con el primer préstamo recibido de Manuela Ramos de S/. 300 decide invertir en la inicial para la compra de un motocar.

En la actualidad cuenta con un negocio de compra y venta de repuestos para motores en su casa, además posee un motocar que presta servicio de transporte .

Con el préstamo de S/. 1,300, el cual pagará en 5 meses, invertirá en la compra de repuestos para motores chinos, repuestos para motores de aserraderos, y piladoras.

Zoila se siente muy feliz y a pesar de su edad y de las dificultades que se le presentaron en la vida sigue saliendo adelante, creciendo con su negocio para el bienestar de su familia y además está muy agradecida por el apoyo que le brinda Manuela Ramos.

loans.use: Purchase of spare parts for mills and peelers.

loans.name: Clavelitas Group

texts.es:
The "Clavelitas" is an enterpreneur women's group with very low profile. These extremely shy women come from Santa Rita de Najuala, a very rural community located in the town of Solola.

Even tough they come from a very humble home, many of them are very successful business women. Seven out of the twenty-five are requesting loans higher than the usual amount, the rest are just requesting the common amount requested. It is very important to point out that this success has been achieved in less than three years.

The majority of these women are weavers who make traditional dresses. Most common items are: huipiles (cotton blouses), cortes (skirts), skirts and shirts.

Many of these women have improved their life because the sell their goods to local merchants. However, with the credit they are requesting, they are hoping to become merchants themselves. The majority of the women are going to use the money to buy fabrics and threads to make these traditional dresses.

They hope to improve their their business, homes and even purchase some land! The success of their business depends of the capital they are able to acquire. This is why your support is so important!

Translated from Spanish by Maria Peterson, Kiva Volunteer.

Las Clavelitas es un grupo de mujeres muy emprendedoras, pero de perfil muy bajo. La timidez yace en que las clientas de este banco comunal provienen de Santa Rita de Nahuala, una comunidad rural muy retirado en el departamento de Sololà.

A pesar de que las clientas provengan de un origen humilde, muchas de ellas son empresarias muy exitosas. Siete de veinte y cinco clientas están solicitando los montos más altos dentro de la institución, mientras que la gran mayoría están solicitando préstamos promedios. Es importante notar que esta carrera éxitosa lo han logrado en cuestión de dos a tres años.

La gran mayoría de mujeres en las Clavelitas son dotadas tejedoras que trabajan elaborando trajes típicos autóctonas del área rural en Guatemala. Los productos más comunes son: huipiles (blusas de algodón), cortes (faldas), fajas y blusas (poliéster).

Estas mujeres salieron adelante en el mundo textil porque antes muchas elaboraban el tejido para un comercializador, sin embargo ahora con el crédito que reciben ellas se han convertido en tejedoras y comercializadoras al mismo tiempo. La mayoría de señoras van a utilizar su préstamo para comprar hilos y tejidos para elaborar sus trajes tradicionales. Otras van a utilizar su préstamo para comprar ganado para su respectiva crianza y venta.

Las señoras de las Clavelitas esperan prosperar para poder ampliar su negocio, su casa o comprar un terreno. El éxito de su negocio depende del capital que puedan obtener para ampliar su negocio. ¡Es por eso que es importante apoyarlas!

loans.use: This loan is going to be used to purchase threads and other goods in order to be able to make traditional dresses. They also hope to buy cattle to sell.

loans.name: Amazonas Group

texts.en:
Amazonas is the name of this association which they identity with the characteristics of: determination, readiness to fight, ability to hunt, persistence to successfully reach objectives for their welfare and that of their family. For the most part, Amazonas dedicates themselves to the tailoring and creation of clothing that they sell in local fairs and in some cases they take them to the center of the country. Currently, they require money to enter into the production and wholesale market. This money will be used to invest in the purchase of materials and skilled labor in order to increase production.

Translated from Spanish by Gabriel Santamaria, Kiva Volunteer.

Amazonas es el nombre de esta Asociación, que ve en las características de estas mujeres guerreras, decididas y cazadoras, su identidad para seguir adelante en los proyectos trazados, para su subsistencia y la de sus familias. En su mayoría, las Amazonas se dedican a la costura y confección de prendas de vestir, las que comercializan en las principales ferias de su zona, y en algunos casos llevan al interior del país. Actualmente ellas precisan de dinero para poder incursionar en la producción y venta mayorista, para esto requieren invertir capital en la compra de materiales y mano de obra calificada que colabore en el incremento de producción.

loans.use: Currently they require money to enter into the production and wholesale market.  This money will be used to invest in the purchase of materials and skilled labor in order to increase production.
